natural problem: Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles. What is the probability that exactly three of the marbles that he removes are green? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth.
natural solution: There is a $\left( \frac{7}{10} \right) ^3 \left( \frac{3}{10} \right) ^3 = \frac{9261}{1000000}$ probability that 3 particular marbles out of 6 will be green and the rest will be purple. There are also  $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways to choose which 3 out of the 6 are the green ones.
Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum> i \<in> {3..6}. (binomial 6 i) * (7 / 10) powr i * (3 / 10) powr (6 - i))"
shows  "probability = 0.185"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles. What is the probability that exactly three of the marbles that he removes are green? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .185
 ### Proof
 There is a $\left( \frac{7}{10} \right) ^3 \left( \frac{3}{10} \right) ^3 = \frac{9261}{1000000}$ probability that 3 particular marbles out of 6 will be green and the rest will be purple. There are also  $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways to choose which 3 out of the 6 are the green ones.
 Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum> i \<in> {3..6}. (binomial 6 i) * (7 / 10) powr i * (3 / 10) powr (6 - i))"
shows  "probability = 0.185"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A 6-sided die has its faces numbered from 1 to 6. The probability of rolling an odd number is $\frac{7}{10}$ and the probability of rolling an even number is $\frac{3}{10}$. What is the probability of rolling at least 3 odd numbers in 6 rolls? The final answer is 0.185.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability 7 3 = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 0 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability n (6 - n) = 6"
and h2 : "binomial 6 3 * (probability 7 3) powr 3 * (1 - probability 7 3) powr 3 = 185 / 1000"
shows  "round (binomial 6 3 * (probability 7 3) powr 3 * (1 - probability 7 3) powr 3) = 185"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles. What is the probability that exactly three of the marbles that he removes are green? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .185
 ### Proof
 There is a $\left( \frac{7}{10} \right) ^3 \left( \frac{3}{10} \right) ^3 = \frac{9261}{1000000}$ probability that 3 particular marbles out of 6 will be green and the rest will be purple. There are also  $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways to choose which 3 out of the 6 are the green ones.
 Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability 7 3 = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 0 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability n (6 - n) = 6"
and h2 : "binomial 6 3 * (probability 7 3) powr 3 * (1 - probability 7 3) powr 3 = 185 / 1000"
shows  "round (binomial 6 3 * (probability 7 3) powr 3 * (1 - probability 7 3) powr 3) = 185"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A probability experiment has two possible outcomes, with probabilities of success and failure given by $p(7, 3) = 10$ and $p(n, 6 - n) = 6$ for $0 \le n \le 6$. If the experiment is conducted 6 times, find the probability of exactly 3 successes and 3 failures, expressed as a fraction. Round the result to the nearest whole number. The final answer is 185.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes green_marbles :: real
and purple_marbles :: real
and total_marbles :: real
and probability_green :: real
and probability_purple :: real
and num_trials :: real
and num_green :: real
and num_purple :: real
and probability_exact_green :: real
assumes h0 : "green_marbles = 7"
and h1 : "purple_marbles = 3"
and h2 : "total_marbles = green_marbles + purple_marbles"
and h3 : "probability_green = green_marbles / total_marbles"
and h4 : "probability_purple = purple_marbles / total_marbles"
and h5 : "num_trials = 6"
and h6 : "num_green = 3"
and h7 : "num_purple = num_trials - num_green"
and h8 : "probability_exact_green = (binomial num_trials num_green) * (probability_green ^ num_green) * (probability_purple ^ num_purple)"
shows  "probability_exact_green = 0.185"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles. What is the probability that exactly three of the marbles that he removes are green? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .185
 ### Proof
 There is a $\left( \frac{7}{10} \right) ^3 \left( \frac{3}{10} \right) ^3 = \frac{9261}{1000000}$ probability that 3 particular marbles out of 6 will be green and the rest will be purple. There are also  $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways to choose which 3 out of the 6 are the green ones.
 Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes green_marbles :: real
and purple_marbles :: real
and total_marbles :: real
and probability_green :: real
and probability_purple :: real
and num_trials :: real
and num_green :: real
and num_purple :: real
and probability_exact_green :: real
assumes h0 : "green_marbles = 7"
and h1 : "purple_marbles = 3"
and h2 : "total_marbles = green_marbles + purple_marbles"
and h3 : "probability_green = green_marbles / total_marbles"
and h4 : "probability_purple = purple_marbles / total_marbles"
and h5 : "num_trials = 6"
and h6 : "num_green = 3"
and h7 : "num_purple = num_trials - num_green"
and h8 : "probability_exact_green = (binomial num_trials num_green) * (probability_green ^ num_green) * (probability_purple ^ num_purple)"
shows  "probability_exact_green = 0.185"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a box, there are 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles. If you draw a total of 6 marbles from the box without replacement, what is the probability that exactly 3 of them are green? The final answer is 0.185.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes green_marbles purple_marbles total_draws :: nat
and probability :: real
assumes h0 : "green_marbles = 7"
and h1 : "purple_marbles = 3"
and h2 : "total_draws = 6"
and h3 : "probability = (binomial_coefficient total_draws (total_draws div 2)) * (green_marbles / (green_marbles + purple_marbles)) powr (total_draws div 2) * (purple_marbles / (green_marbles + purple_marbles)) powr (total_draws div 2)"
shows  "probability = 0.185"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles. What is the probability that exactly three of the marbles that he removes are green? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .185
 ### Proof
 There is a $\left( \frac{7}{10} \right) ^3 \left( \frac{3}{10} \right) ^3 = \frac{9261}{1000000}$ probability that 3 particular marbles out of 6 will be green and the rest will be purple. There are also  $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways to choose which 3 out of the 6 are the green ones.
 Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes green_marbles purple_marbles total_draws :: nat
and probability :: real
assumes h0 : "green_marbles = 7"
and h1 : "purple_marbles = 3"
and h2 : "total_draws = 6"
and h3 : "probability = (binomial_coefficient total_draws (total_draws div 2)) * (green_marbles / (green_marbles + purple_marbles)) powr (total_draws div 2) * (purple_marbles / (green_marbles + purple_marbles)) powr (total_draws div 2)"
shows  "probability = 0.185"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a box, there are 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles. If you draw 6 marbles without replacement, what is the probability that you will draw an equal number of green and purple marbles (3 of each)? The final answer is 0.185.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes green marbles purple marbles total_marbles withdrawn_marbles :: real
assumes h0 : "green marbles = 7"
and h1 : "purple marbles = 3"
and h2 : "total_marbles = green marbles + purple marbles"
and h3 : "withdrawn_marbles = 6"
and h4 : "exactly_three_green = (binomial_coefficient withdrawn_marbles 3) * (green marbles / total_marbles) powr 3 * (purple marbles / total_marbles) powr 3"
shows  "exactly_three_green \<approx> 0.185"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes green marbles purple marbles total_marbles withdrawn_marbles :: real
assumes h0 : "green marbles = 7"
and h1 : "purple marbles = 3"
and h2 : "total_marbles = green marbles + purple marbles"
and h3 : "withdrawn_marbles = 6"
and h4 : "exactly_three_green = (binomial_coefficient withdrawn_marbles 3) * (green marbles / total_marbles) powr 3 * (purple marbles / total_marbles) powr 3"
shows  "exactly_three_green \<approx> 0.185"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a jar, there are 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles. If you randomly withdraw 6 marbles from the jar, what is the probability that exactly 3 of them will be green? The final answer is approximately 0.185.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i=0..6. (binomial 6 i) * (7/10) powr i * (3/10) powr (6 - i))"
and h1 : "round (P * 1000) = 185"
shows  "P = 0.185"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles.  *)

fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i=0..6. (binomial 6 i) * (7/10) powr i * (3/10) powr (6 - i))"
and h1 : "round (P * 1000) = 185"

a_5.informal problem: A probability experiment has 6 trials, where the probability of success in each trial is 7/10 and the probability of failure is 3/10. Find the probability, P, of the given experiment. If the probability is rounded to the nearest thousandth, it is 0.185.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability_green probability_purple :: real
and trials outcomes :: nat
assumes h0 : "probability_green = 7 / 10"
and h1 : "probability_purple = 3 / 10"
and h2 : "trials = 6"
and h3 : "outcomes = binomial trials 3"
shows  "real (outcomes) * (probability_green powr 3) * (probability_purple powr (trials - 3)) = 0.185"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles. What is the probability that exactly three of the marbles that he removes are green? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .185
 ### Proof
 There is a $\left( \frac{7}{10} \right) ^3 \left( \frac{3}{10} \right) ^3 = \frac{9261}{1000000}$ probability that 3 particular marbles out of 6 will be green and the rest will be purple. There are also  $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways to choose which 3 out of the 6 are the green ones.
 Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability_green probability_purple :: real
and trials outcomes :: nat
assumes h0 : "probability_green = 7 / 10"
and h1 : "probability_purple = 3 / 10"
and h2 : "trials = 6"
and h3 : "outcomes = binomial trials 3"
shows  "real (outcomes) * (probability_green powr 3) * (probability_purple powr (trials - 3)) = 0.185"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a set of 6 trials, the probability of drawing a green object is 7/10 and the probability of drawing a purple object is 3/10. Calculate the probability of drawing exactly 3 green objects and 3 purple objects in these 6 trials. The final answer is 0.185.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability (\<lambda> x. x = 7) = 7 / 10"
and h1 : "probability (\<lambda> x. x = 3) = 3 / 10"
and h2 : "binomial_coefficient 6 3 * (probability (\<lambda> x. x = 7)) powr 3 * (probability (\<lambda> x. x = 3)) powr 3 = 0.185"
shows  "0.185 = binomial_coefficient 6 3 * (probability (\<lambda> x. x = 7)) powr 3 * (probability (\<lambda> x. x = 3)) powr 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles. What is the probability that exactly three of the marbles that he removes are green? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .185

 Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability (\<lambda> x. x = 7) = 7 / 10"
and h1 : "probability (\<lambda> x. x = 3) = 3 / 10"
and h2 : "binomial_coefficient 6 3 * (probability (\<lambda> x. x = 7)) powr 3 * (probability (\<lambda> x. x = 3)) powr 3 = 0.185"
shows  "0.185 = binomial_coefficient 6 3 * (probability (\<lambda> x. x = 7)) powr 3 * (probability (\<lambda> x. x = 3)) powr 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a certain probability distribution, the probability of the outcome 7 is $\frac{7}{10}$, and the probability of the outcome 3 is $\frac{3}{10}$. Calculate the probability of having exactly 3 outcomes of 7 and 3 outcomes of 3 in 6 independent trials. The final answer is 0.185.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes green_marbles purple_marbles total_marbles tries :: real
assumes h0 : "green_marbles = 7"
and h1 : "purple_marbles = 3"
and h2 : "total_marbles = green_marbles + purple_marbles"
and h3 : "tries = 6"
shows  "prob_exactly_three_green = 0.185"

a_8.informal problem: In a bag, there are 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles. If you draw a marble 6 times with replacement, what is the probability of drawing exactly 3 green marbles? The final answer is 0.185.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes green_marbles purple_marbles total_marbles withdrawn_marbles :: real
assumes h0 : "green_marbles = 7"
and h1 : "purple_marbles = 3"
and h2 : "total_marbles = green_marbles + purple_marbles"

shows  "exactly_three_green = 0.185"
